content.description:
P1: 5.7

P2: 5.8

P3: 5.9



Start where B2 has been spray painted on the rock.

Bolts and fixed anchors.

" An excellent route on solid, interesting rock. Start at an obvious Left leaning water worn gully/chimney system between "C3" and "D1"".

This route climbs an interesting continuous straight feature, which breaks up the sharp prickly limestone slab with some off-width stemming, crack climbing, and blocky jugs. Still, the cruxes are all limestone slab moves which some find unpleasant. 

"P1: 5.7, 20m, 6 bolts. 2 bolt anchor with quicklinks"

Fairly straightforward. Follow the groove and make some moves around left of it, then traverse back into the gully. Anchors easy to find up and slightly left, decent belay stance.

"P2: 5.6, 20m, 4 bolts - Rap ring anchors"

Easy climb through a nice gully to a tree by the anchors. Crux has some interesting pockets. wide ledge, good for a break. 

"P3: 5.7, 40m, 8 bolts- Rap ring anchors"

Very fun moves broken up by standard prickly slab. Felt shorter than 40 m.

"P4: 5.7, 25m, 9 bolts- Rap ring anchors"

Stemming in a chimney, then onto a slab again. 

"P5: 5.9) 45m, 14 bolts - bolt anchor with chains"

climb past 2 bolts and another set of rap rings, important for the descent. Crux is very well-bolted low-percentage slab moves near the middle. anchors aren't quite on top of the ridge.



Abraham slabs is visible from the 11 Highway, and if you slow down the trail is easy to see just west of the feature. Follow the trail, take the flagged left fork and eventually meet up with the wall. Pass spray-painted "B1" and "B2", then "C1, C2, C3". The left-leaning groove is easy to find.

Rappel descent: I used a 70m. TIE KNOTS IN THE END. Use the intermediate rap station on P5 as well as the P4 anchors, a 70 m won't reach all the way to P3.

Bolts and Rap anchors.

Follow 11 bolts through the roof.


Bolts and anchors

3 pitches of approach climbing for 2 money pitches of slab-crack! Wear your helmet, and consider bringing shoes to walk off.

P1: 5.6 RX: Start at "D3" painted on the rock, heading up a short left facing corner (low 5th) to gain a sloping ledge. Reach up and clip your first and only bolt (6-8 m off the deck), trend slightly left but mostly up, following the path of least resistance. There is a horizontal hand-sized slot (BD #2), this was my last piece of pro. Continue up another 10 meters, and mind the rock, it becomes progressively more dreadful as you near the top-out ledge. Don't even think about pulling out on any of the flake holds! 
(25 m, 1 quick draw, 1 hand sized cam. Gear anchor- look slightly to your left, BD # 0.75, 0.5, and 0.2-0.4)

P2: 4th Class: Head up and left along the ledge system, passing a tree along the way. Finish at an alcove with a bolted belay- a new Fixe bolt with a rap ring and an old school metolius rap hanger. Protect the traverse with cams from BD #0.5-2 if you want, but many parties will be comfortable scrambling without pro. 
(40 m, 2 bolt anchor)

P3: 5.6 RX: From the alcove, step back to the right, and head up the left slanting weakness in the rock. Follow the path of least resistance to a tree'd ledge above, with a bolted/rap ring stance plumb to your climbing line. The crux comes just a couple of moves after leaving the alcove, there is a spot for a finger sized cam (BD 0.4) which sort of protects the hardest portion of this pitch. Rock becomes more marginal higher on this pitch and pro is scarce.
(35+ m, BD # 0.4, 1, 2 bolt anchor)

P4/5: 5.8: You have now been deposited at the base of the awe inspiring namesake hidden crack. You know what to do! From the bolted belay stance, walk right, pulling a couple of slab moves back up and to the left to gain the crack. Gear is a bit finicky, especially just off the deck. The crack offers limited true crack climbing, but the slab on either side is highly featured. 
P4: 30 m, cams 0.2-3, nuts. Extend your first few pieces. 2-bolt semi-hanging belay.
P5: 45? m, cams 0.2-3, nuts, 5 bolts, 2 pins. After the crack disappears follow the bolt line up and right on easy slab. After the last bolt, continue another half meter to the right and then punch straight up through the less than confidence inspiring rock and continue up along a left facing corner. Once you top out, look up and to your left for a 2 bolt belay station. 

Descent: Walk off- head down the ridge, no down-climbing involved. The trail becomes more clear as you get lower, and is sparsely flagged in select places to mark passes around small cliff bands

Rack: Helmet! Nuts (preferably offset), cams from finger to big hands (BD 0.2-3). Depending on how bold you plan on being, consider bringing doubles from 0.4-0.75, and even doubles at 1-2. 7+ draws and at least a handful of alpines. No need for big cams despite the 2 m of off-width; smaller pro at the back, good pro before and after, plus, you don't have to climb the section as off-width.  

Linking Pitches: Don't. Rope drag is not an issue for linking P4/5, but rope length may be.

Walk uphill perhaps 200 meters along the base of the slabs, passing the large flared giant crack/small chimney feature that bisects the face. Stop when you reach "D3" painted on the rock: look directly above this for a lone bolt some 6-8 meters up, this is your line!
Cams 0.2-3, nuts, 7 draws and a handful of alpines.

Just left of A3 painted on the rock.


Bolts

climbs.name: Pacemaker
climbs.fa: M. Adolph, Marcel p., Monty A., Dave K. 2003

content.description:
"The farthest right of the 3 multipitch sport routes. Rap with a 60m rope or walk off."

-This is from the most recent David Thompson guidebook. Oddly, while climbing, you can see a 4-pitch route climber's right which is not listed in the book. It looks like quite new hardware so it may be more recent than the book.

"P1: 5.7, 29m, 8 bolts. Rap rings on top of this pitch."

-Most moves are friction climbing on small holds. Overall slabbiest pitch. Well-protected. Double rap ring anchor, with the least comfortable belay stance of all the pitches (small ledge, cannot go no-hands unless hanging on anchor). Consider clipping anchor and linking to P2 for a more comfortable belay.

"P2: 5.8, 26m, 6 bolts."

-Many good holds, broken up by thin slabby faces, with a bit of a runout from second-last bolt to anchor. Some loose rock which look like good holds so beware. Double rap rings at a comfortable belay stance.

"P3: 5.7, 19m, 5 bolts."

-Mostly good holds, less slabby than first two pitches. Double rap ring anchor, comfortable belay ledge.

P4: 5.7+, 22m, 6 bolts."

-Good holds except for one slabby thin technical face with some committing moves 15m up. After this, the rest of the moves are likely 5.5. As of 2021 the anchor has 3 bolt hangers: 1 empty, 1 with new quicklink, and one with a rusty quicklink. There are at least two bolts visible above, on some scrambly terrain with big ledges.

-Overall, the bolt lines are very straight, no runners needed. Rapping with 60 m rope is simple. Pulling the rope always brings a few small pieces off the wall so keep your helmeted head down when pulling.



Walk up the approach trail for Abraham Slabs, pass beyond the B2 spraypainted in white on the wall. There is eventually a raised flat ledge with several climbs. This one starts 3 bolt lines left of a tall right-facing corner. 

Bolts up to 8 per pitch, max. 15 if linking pitches. Anchors: rap rings or quicklink hangers.

The enormous SW facing grey limestone slab at the toe of Abraham Mountain hosts numerous climbs. Climbs include single pitch sport to multi-pitch trad on cheese-grater limestone typical of the area. For the most part, climbs are...slab! This sector is fantastically situated above Lake Abraham, and gets afternoon and evening sun.

More info:
http://www.coe.ca/index.htm
https://www.girthhitchguiding.ca/development-and-community 

The cause:  ca.gofundme.com/f/david-tho…
